prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SG1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Measure the CO(4-3) line flux of a z~3 Quasar host galaxy and spatially resolve the line to estimate a dynamical mass.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For each object, we tune one baseband to the CO line at a spectral resolution of 3 km/s, and the remaining three to the adjacent continuum.

We expect the gas to be extended out to scales of 1 arcsec based on our narrow-band imaging tracing [OIII] in J0748. A resolution of 0.1 arcsec is required to securely resolve the source into about 100 beams.

The CO gas mass in our targets was estimated by the sensitive upper limit of stellar mass based on the Subaru AO-assisted 0.3 arcsec-resolution imaging and assuming conservatively that Mstell=Mgas. This assumption, for example, accurately estimates the dynamical mass for the Willott et al. 2015 AGN, whose hosts are similar to our targets. We then estimate the CO luminosities by converting our CO gas masses (typically >10^10 Msol) into luminosites assuming a ULIRG-like conversion factor of 0.8. The extreme CO luminosity expected in these systems even with the most conservative assumptions allows us to spatially resolve the host into ~100 resolution elements and dynamically resolve the line into 40 km/s resolution at the proposed RMS, 0.5 mJy/beam. The unlikely scenario of non-detection at this depth will result in a groundbreaking case study that can show that BH growth can preceed galaxy growth and only external processes can regulate the growth of the stellar component to reach the known scaling relations today.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The physical mechanism of the blackhole-host galaxy co-evolution is one of the most important questions in astrophysics. We propose to observe a unique sample of quasars with extreme stellar mass (M*) deficit compared to the measured blackhole (BH) mass at z ~ 3, the peak epoch of the active galactic nucleus accretion history. These quasars are drawn from 70 quasars at z ~ 3 whose host are studied with Subaru AO-assisted imaging. While we detected stellar components for most, the quasars proposed here have >10x deficit in bulge M* compared to the BH mass, which can serve as a testbed for the co-evolution mechanism. We expect a substantial amount of gas to be present in these hosts but not yet formed enough stars for a massive host galaxy, and hence the extreme CO luminosities that will allow spatially and dynamically resolved CO lines observations. Together with our sensitive M* limits, we will use the gas and dynamical mass estimates to either confirm that these hosts will be able to move onto the well established local BH-host scaling relations, or if the gas content is too low, indicating that mergers and/or gas inflows have a major impact on their evolution.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe, The University of Tokyo
Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe, The University of Tokyo
